head.supplied: 8 Victoria Chambers, ¶ Victoria Street, ¶ Westminster, ¶ s.w ¶ . ¶ 5th May, ¶ 18 ¶ 82 ¶ Sir,...

div.p: W82/5372, unit 1294, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; font-style: italic;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end; font-style: italic;

div.p:
I have the honour to inform you that on the 23rd of last December I received a despatch from the Colonial Office enclosing a copy of a despatch addressed to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs by Her Majesty's Consul at Mobile, stating that Seeds of the Southern Long Leaf Pine, which had been some years sought for planting in Australia, could now be obtained, and asking whether I should wish to order a supply for the Government Botanical Department. I enclose a copy of Consul Cridland's despatch.
On 26 November 1881 F. Cridland, British Consulate, Mobile, wrote to Earl Granville, Foreign Office: 'I have the honour to state to your Lordship that a Mr Daniel E. Langdon of this City having heard that some parties in England connected with Her Majesty's Government had one or two years ago sent out to the United States to procure the seed of the Southern long leaf Pine (Pinus Australis of Michaux Pinus Palustrus of Lambert) for planting in Australia, has applied to me for information on the subject. Mr Langdon states that for several years past the pine seed crop has failed, but that this year there is an abundant one and that he has gathered one hundred pounds of the above named pine seed which he will be most happy to forward to any person in England who might still want the same if the above report is true. The cost of the seed would be one dollar and fifty cents per pound or about six shillings and three pence. To oblige Mr Langdon who is personally well known to me as one of the most respectable agriculturalists in the State I have promised to place the above before your Lordship'.
2. Sir Joseph Hooker having also been refered to by the Colonial Offive on the subject wrote in reply as follows: —

"Sir Joseph Hooker has no knowledge of the matter beyond what is disclosed in Mr Consul Cridland's letter. Having regard, however, to the great commercial value of the turpentine derived from this tree Sir Joseph Hooker thinks that it would be well worth the consideration of the Agent-General for Victoria whether he would not assume the responsibility of securing a quantity of the Seed for his Government. It is recommended by Sir Ferdinand von Mueller in his 'Select plants for industrial culture in extra Tropical Countries'."

"If the Secretary of State should be pleased to take any action in the matter little time should be lost as Pine Seed does not long retain its capacity of germination. The tree though very beautiful is unsuited to the climate of this Country."

3. Under the circumstances I decided to order ten pounds of the Seed, and they have been delivered in time for transmission by my mail box of the present mail. Having regard to Sir Joseph Hooker's remark that Pine Seed does not long retain its capacity for germination, I would suggest that the packages, with a copy of this correspondence, be transmitted to the Government Botanist without delay.
The seeds were forwarded to the Curator of the Botanic and Domain Gardens, W. Guilfoyle, who replied with an outline of their intended distribution on 16 June 1882.
